summary: This document is a chain of emails from September 2019 between U.S. Department of Justice officials and an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York, discussing coordination with the Paris prosecutor's office regarding their investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's potential connections to France. The emails focus on scheduling calls and establishing protocols for sharing information while considering confidentiality concerns.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The primary SDNY prosecutor corresponding with DOJ officials about coordinating with French authorities on the Epstein case, discussing information sharing and confidentiality.

persons.name: DOJ Attaché/Magistrat de liaison américain U.S. Embassy, Paris
persons.role: DOJ official at the U.S. Embassy in Paris
persons.context: The DOJ liaison in Paris who initiated contact with SDNY prosecutors regarding an inquiry from the Paris prosecutor's office about Epstein's connections to France, facilitating communication between U.S. and French authorities.

connections.person2: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.description: Colleagues within the U.S. Department of Justice coordinating on international aspects of the Epstein investigation, specifically regarding information sharing with French authorities.

events.title: Initial inquiry about French investigation

personsInvolved: DOJ Attaché/Magistrat de liaison américain U.S. Embassy, Paris
Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: The Paris prosecutor's office was actively investigating Jeffrey Epstein's potential connections to France as of September 2019.
French authorities were preparing to execute search warrants in their Epstein investigation, possibly as early as the week following September 6, 2019.
The Paris prosecutor's office assured U.S. officials that shared information would remain confidential until a criminal defendant was placed under examination in France.
U.S. and French authorities were coordinating to avoid interfering with each other's investigations while potentially sharing helpful information.
The email chain shows international coordination between U.S. DOJ officials in Paris and SDNY prosecutors regarding the global aspects of the Epstein investigation.
